comment.narrative: Draft National Gender Policy in Place but there is no implementation strategy 0 institutionalization of gender responsive budgeting and GEPMI Limited expertise in mainstreaming gender in economic policy planning

1. National Gender policy further revised to include SDGs 2. Newly established Gender Commission supported with vehicle and computers 3.50 Women supported to participate at the Zimbabwe Trade Fair . 4. Stampmill fitted and Commissioning of the Stampmill 5. Framework for the establishment of the Women 's Microfinace Bank Finalized 6. Framework to implement the JPGE Pillar 2 Activities through the Zimbabwe Gender Commission with the assitance of an academic institution established

1. A consultant was hired to include SDG and the Draft revised Policy was adopted by Cabinet in November 2016. 2.The ZGC was provided with a second hand vehicle 3. 50 women participated at the Zimbabwe Trade Fair , they first received training . Women reported securing markets , from, SADC, China , Austria and Brazil 4.The stampmill procured for the Mtandazo Women Miners Cooperative had all the related equipment procured , 70 Women miners including 32 members of the Mthandazo Cooperative, trained in how to use the stampmill , health safety , environmental and gender issues and received certificates , women reported increased skills in small scale commercial mining. 5. Framework to establish Women 's Microfinance Bank finalized and Board of Directors appointed . 6. Concep note on justification of implementing the JPGE through the Zimbabwe Gender Commission Developed and the Souther and Eastern Africa Women 's Law Center contracted to assist the ZGC and the Ministry of Women Affairs , accelerate the politically sensitive pillar 2 of JPGE on Political Participation of Women , activities set to start in 2017

1. Launch of the Reviewed National Gender Policy and dissemination of the policy 2. Gender Focal Points trained in Gender Mainstreaming and Gender Equality Constitutional Provisions 3.Support the development of the Strategic Plan for the Women 's Microfinance Bank 4. Ministry of Women Affairs Officials supported to participate at the Commission on the Status of Women 5. Three Provincial Gender Dialogues and one National Gender Forum conducted 6. Four all stakeholder consultaions on the development of a national strategy conducted

1. Contribution to public awareness raising on the contents of the gender policy and gender equality constitutional provisions as well as appreciation of international and regional gender equality and women empowerment instruments was achieved through the launch of National Gender Policy in July 2017 in Harare. Presentations by the Minister for Gender, the Chairperson of the Zimbabwe Gender Commission and the Chairperson of the Gender Parliament Portfolio Committee and the UNDP Country Director as well as CSOs and UNWOMEN provided a platform for the public to appreciate issues of gender equality and women empowerment, including SDG 5. The launch attracted 300 people (female and male) from the public sector, private sector academic institutions, youth, CSOs, religious and traditional leaders.
The TORS to develop the National Gender Policy Implementation Strategy were developed and the IP received candidates who are yet to be interviewed. The intervention was deferred to allow, collaboration with UNWOMEN
2.Action Plans to improve gender mainstreaming in Government ministries and Departments were produced following training of Forty-seven (47) Gender Focal Points (GFP)-female and male in Gender Mainstreaming and Gender Equality Constitutional Provisions including the provisions of the Approved National Revised Gender Policy as well as the SDGs, especially SDG 5. This was in preparation of the GFP in dissemination and implementation of the revised gender policy.
3. The Strategic Plan for the Womens Microfinance Bank was developed. The newly appointed board members comprised of both female and male experts from mostly the banking, accounting, ICT, entrepreneurial development backgrounds were trained in gender sensitive microfinance banking to enhance the board members appreciation of their roles and financial inclusion. An organizational development framework was supported and further support was given in professional recruitment of the Banks CEO, Fi

description.narrative: Scaling up adaptation in Zimbabwe, with a focus on rural livelihoods with the purpose of diversifying livelihoods and income in order to strengthen climate resilience.
populated place

activity-description.narrative: Climate Change Adaptation and DRM

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Indicators as in AWP 2016
Output 1 Diversified and strengthened livelihoods and sources of income for vulnerable smallholder farmers in project area. Indicators: - Households and communities have more secure livelihood asset base (5 point rating) disaggregated by gender - Increase in agricultural and other sources of income - Number of financial transactions per Self Help Group increase - Volume of targeted locally produced commodities that are processed/value added and marketed by smallholder farmers increase
End of project targets: -Percentage of households with a rating of 4 on scale: Secure access to livelihood assets, increased by at least 20%. -50% of targeted smallholder farmers (by gender) have increased their agricultural income by at least 25%. -At least 50% of female headed households in each Self Help Group complete at least two financial transactions -At least 25% of targeted locally produced commodities in the three districts have value added and marketed by smallholder farmers
Output 2: Increased knowledge and understanding of climate variability and change-induced risks in targeted vulnerable areas Indicators: - Relevant climate risk information disseminated to stakeholders - Climate information routinely and effectively used in making climate sensitive decisions
End of project targets: -70% of smallholder farmers in the project area have access to localised climate forecasts - Climate information being routinely and effectively used by at least 50% of smallholder farmers (by gender) to make climate sensitive decisions.
Output 3: Monitoring, learning, adaptive feedback and evaluation Indicators: - Effective selection and implementation of adaptation measures
Output 4: Project management Indicators: - Delivery rate

comment.narrative:
Baseline data as described in AWP 2016
Output 1 Diversified and strengthened livelihoods and sources of income for vulnerable smallholder farmers in project area. Baseline: - Households in project area have poor access (rating 2) to livelihood assets - Baseline agricultural income per household. Buhera $444/year, Chimanimani $864/year and Chiredzi $456 /year. - Number of existing financial self help groups and baseline financial transactions. Buhera 18,3%, Chimanimani 26,7% and Chiredzi 15,1%. - Three (3) short value chains to be targeted (Buhera: Goat, cattle, sorghum, honey. Chimanimani: Potato, goats, honey, beans, pepper and Chiredzi: Sorghum, pearl millet, cattle and goats). The baseline volume of products marketed to be determined.
Output 2: Increased knowledge and understanding of climate variability and change-induced risks in targeted vulnerable areas Baseline - Smallholder farmers in target districts do not have access to regular localised climate forecasts and protocols for effective use in risk management (Buhera 71,7%, Chimanimani 76,4% and Chiredzi 65,3%) - Climate information not routinely used by stakeholders in the targeted districts
Output 3: Monitoring, learning, adaptive feedback and evaluation Baseline: - Adaptation measures that work well in the targeted areas not clearly established
Output 4: Project management

Output 1 Diversified and strengthened livelihoods and sources of income for vulnerable smallholder farmers in project area. Targets: - Cumulatively 9,800 households, being 2000 households in Buhera, 3500 (Chimanimani) and 4300 (Chiredzi) increasing livelihood asset base from the implemented strategic integrated micro-watershed CCA investments implemented. - Cumulatively 1800 female headed households in each targeted micro-watershed have improved access to financial services and financial transactions per Self Help Group increase by 25% over the baseline - Cumulatively 600 households in each of the three targeted value chains have improved market literacy and linkages with markets and service providers, and their volume of marketed products increase by 20% over the baseline. - Agricultural and income from other sources among at least 25% of the farmers participating in the project increase by at least 20% over the baseline.
Output 2: Increased knowledge and understanding of climate variability and change-induced risks in targeted vulnerable areas Targets: - (4,400 households) being 800 households in Buhera, 1800 in Chimanimani and 1800 in Chiredzi receiving relevant climate risk information. - 25% of targeted farmers routinely and effectively using climate information to make climate sensitive decisions. - Stakeholders have capacity to reach at least 25% of targeted beneficiaries with improved climate services for climate risk management
Output 3: Monitoring, learning, adaptive feedback and evaluation Targets: - Monitoring results supporting the longterm process of learning (what works) and adjustments of adaptation choices to enhance project impact - Project communication influencing other projects, geographical areas, policy makers and wider public to promote scaling up
Output 4: Project management Targets: - 100% delivery - Project managed effectively - Project is visible at local, national and international levels

Output1:Diversified and strengthened livelihoods and sources of income for vulnerable smallholder farmers in project area. End of project target: (Cumulatively 9,800 households) being 2,000 households in Buhera, 3,500 (Chimanimani) and 4,300 (Chiredzi) increasing livelihood asset base from the implemented strategic integrated micro-watershed CCA investments implemented Progress: Cumulatively 3,941 households (2006 males, 1935 females) being 1248 households (649 males,599 females) in Buhera, 1648 households(930 males, 718 females) in Chimanimani and 1045 households (427 males, 618 females) in Chiredzi) have improved access to livelihood asset to build resilience to impacts of climate shocks through investments in water, climate smart agriculture, DRR training and natural ecosystem managements. Access to water has reached 3,069 households across the three districts and 7,273 people were reached through awareness campaigns on climate change and watershed management.
Target: Cumulatively 1800 female headed households in each targeted micro-watershed have improved access to financial services and financial transactions per Self Help Group increase by 25% over the baseline Progress: Trainings in financial literacy resulted in 303 households (11 males, 292 females) in Buhera, 249 households (72males, 177 females) in Chimanimani and 898 households (238males, 660 females) having improved access to financial services through formation of Village Savings and Lending Associations (VSLAs) in total 1450 households trained in 2016. A cumulative total of 102 VSLA groups were established and remain functional (57 Chiredzi, 22 Chimanimani and 23 Buhera). In Chiredzi District, 25 groups had saved a total of US$36,442.73, in Buhera 16 groups saved US$11,640 and in Chimanimani 14 groups saved US$2,392 by end of December 2016. Some of the groups shared out their saved funds at the end of December 2016. In Chiredzi 9 groups shared out $18,600, in Buhera 3 groups shared out $6,

Output targets 2017: Outputs 1.1: Three strategic adaptation Investments developed and implemented in each of the targeted microwatershed of Odzi, Save, Nuanetsi/Runde in Chimanimani, Buhera and Chiredzi Districts Cumulative target: 2000 households reached through adaptive investments in Buhera. 3750 households reached though adaptive investments in Chimanimani. 4350 households reached though adaptive investments in Chiredzi. (10100 in total)
Output 1.2. Inclusive Financial services established to support climate risk management to benefit at least 3000 women Cumulative target: 1800 households reached through village savings and lending
Output 1.3. Market linkages for 3000 households and 3 short value chains established. Cumulative target: 1000 households linked to markets. Honey, cattle, goats, sorghum value chain promoted in Buhera. Beans value chain promoted in Chimanimani. Sorghum, beef, honey, beans value chains promoted in Chiredzi.
Output 2.1 One district and three (3) WARD level Climate User- Interface Platforms for agriculture and DRM established and operational. Target: Operationalisation of the CUIP through dissemination of weather and climate information using the SMS system
Output 2.2 Capacity of service providers and users to enable all activities of the Framework for Climate Services to occur, be scaled up and to have climate services reach at least 70% of targeted beneficiaries developed. Target: MSD supported to produce weekly products, monitor observation equipment,
Output 3.1. M&E plan established. Target: Profile all the reached beneficiaries (10100 households)
Output 3.2Knowledge Management and communication platform to support Learning, project visibility and facilitate replication established Target: Produce 2 newsletters, MSC stories, indepth analysis of adaptive investments

Outputs 1.1: Three strategic adaptation Investments developed and implemented in each of the targeted microwatershed of Odzi, Save, Nuanetsi/Runde in Chimanimani, Buhera and Chiredzi Districts. Cumulative end of project target: 2000 households reached through adaptive investments in Buhera. 3750 households reached though adaptive investments in Chimanimani. 4350 households reached though adaptive investments in Chiredzi. (10100 in total) Results as per Sep 2017: 4610 households (2153 M, 2457 F) have been reached across the three districts with water, natural ecosystem management and CSA practices. (Buhera, 1,282 HHs 667 M, 615 F; Chimanimani 1858 HHs 1028 M, 830 F; Chiredzi, 1470 HHs 458 M, 1012 F)
Output 1.2. Inclusive Financial services established to support climate risk management to benefit at least 3000 women. Cumulative end of project target: 1800 households reached through village savings and lending. Results as per Sep 2017: Beneficiaries remained at 2330 people (1910 F, 420 M), across the three districts in 51 groups in Buhera (637 people, 72 M, 565 F), 22 groups in Chimanimani (249 people, 72 M, 177 F) and 132 groups in Chiredzi (1444 people 276 M, 1168 F).
Output 1.3. Market linkages for 3000 households and 3 short value chains established. Cumulative end of project target: 1000 households linked to markets. Honey, cattle, goats, sorghum value chain promoted in Buhera. Beans value chain promoted in Chimanimani. Sorghum, beef, honey, beans value chains promoted in Chiredzi. Results as per Sep 2017: There was an increase in market linkages to 1761 hhs (872M, 889 F) having secured markets for Michigan pea bean (Cairns), honey (Organoseven, Heavenly Delights, Keans honey), goats (Koala), cattle (Montana), sorghum (Delta, Tongaat Hullet, Grain Marketing Board). Buhera, 569 hhs (322 M, 247 F) linked with Cairns, Organoseven, Heavenly Delights, Keans honey, Montana Meats, and Chimanimani, 350 hhs (201 M, 149 F)) linked with Cairns and Chiredzi,

1.a By December 2017, 9 pieces of legislation had been passed by Parliament and assented to by the President out of an annual target of 12. These include the Constitutional Amendment Bill No. 1, Movable Property Security Bill and the Public Procurement and Disposal of Public Assets Bill.
1.b One Liaison Coordinating Committee - chaired by the Speaker of the National Assembly and comprised of the Presiding Officers, chairpersons of the Portfolio and thematic committees and caucus as well as the whips was held in Bulawayo in October 2017, and resolutions passed included expedition of alignment of key economic and political governance laws to the Constitution through regular engagement with the Executive (Attorney General Office and Ministry of Justice). Relations with the Executive in respect to alignment of laws to the Constitution were strengthened through participation and presentations by the Permanent Secretary in the Ministry of Justice and the Attorney General. The inclusion of these two officials contributed to increased appreciation of the law making process, especially the role of the executive amongst the MPs and the senior staff members
1.c Ten (10 ) Committee Workplans were produced in line with the Parliament of Zimbabwe ( POZ) Institutional Strategic plan focussing on key interventions to be carried around MPs oversight and legislative roles such as fact finding missions to interrogate the non-performing government /public enterprises and call the executive to order
1.d By December 2017, six (6) baseline studies covering legislative Analysis, Gender issues, Human Rights and the rule of Law, Environment and Climate, Economic Literacy and Portfolio Committee systems were produced highlighting the areas and needs for further capacity building. The Baseline studies reports will inform the development of modules and induction of MPs to be conducted in 2018 after the harmonized elections. These are now accessible on electronic devices for MPs a

OUTPUT 1: Application of evidence in policy making for resilience increased. -National risk and hazard profile for resilience building endorsed A National multi hazard index was developed to the lowest administrative level (ward level) accompanied by hazard specific and combined maps. The products were endorsed by a multi stakeholder workshop in September 2015. However, the publication was completed and disseminated to a wider audience during the reporting period. Moreover, a total of 36 multi hazard maps produced to date to inform resilience planning and programming.
-M&E system developed During the second quarter of 2016, Zimbabwe resilience building fund Monitoring, Evaluation & Learning Strategic Framework, including Log frame was developed and circulated for comments to the development partners. Following constructive feedback, the Monitoring, Evaluation and Learning (MEAL) framework was developed & presented during the August 2016 Steering Committee meeting and shared for review and sign off. Furthermore, ZRBFs overall log frame has been developed and signed off on 14th September, 2016.
-Consensus around Theory of Change built The TOC were validated and endorsed by a multi stakeholder workshop in January 2016. TOC development: the problem tree analysis, and a study on risks and vulnerabilities in the cross field between Gender, Climate Change and Livelihood was undertaken to feed into the development of the Theory of Change for ZRBF. The study contributed significantly to the development of the Theory of Change
- Application of evidence in planning for resilience work in Zimbabwe One key point identified in the Zimbabwe resilience strategic framework was the need for evidence to determine contributing factors, the context, types of hazards and relationships between the hazards and wellbeing outcomes. The ZRBF analytical products were developed to fulfil this need as well inform the ZRBF Theory of Change. The key products were Hazards Mapping, Cor

Target ZRBF Monitoring, evaluation & Learning strategic framework program and projects level indicators were harmonized. 1.4 Number of community projects that utilize evidence for improved resilience in communities. Target: 9 districts

OUTPUT 2: Training community leaders in management of social safety nets. Seed bank management training was conducted across the targeted districts. (100% achieved) Training of ISAL groups was deferred to next quarter. 4,150 farmers trained and mobilised into the following groups: LANN, ISALs, burial societies, social safety nets, youth, crop, small livestock (35% achieved) Training builders family wells, granaries and livestock housing. A total of 108 Community builders trained from a target of 114. (95% achievement)
OUTPUT 3:Appropriate, predictable, coordinated and timely response to risks and shocks established from the resilience perspective
Under ECRAS Project Spares for the rehabilitation of 25 Boreholes in Chiredzi and 16 in Mwenezi were procured and distributed to the sites. Of these, 14 boreholes were rehabilitated in Mwenezi. 401 farmers were trained in silage making.
Under MELANA Project 578 out of 581 (99%)Water Point Committees were trained. The training aimed at equipping the community with the requisite skills for the day to day management of the boreholes. The training took place in the 4 districts. 49 out of targeted 49 (100%) Village Pump Minders (VPM) were trained 52 out of targeted 52(100%) boreholes were rehabilitated 58 out of targeted 63(92%) boreholes were repaired 9 out of targeted 19 (47%)boreholes were drilled No dip wells were done. The target was 3

Output 1: Scaled up action on climate change adaptation and mitigation in vulnerable districts is funded and implemented i. Five potential adaptation and mitigation rural projects identified in vulnerable districts ii. Detailed assesments conducted on each project iii. Progress towards NAP iv. Progress towards Low Carbon Development Strategy v. Progress towards district level gender and climate sensitive DRM plans vi. Renewable Energy Policy finalized vii. Forestry Policy finalized viii. Two project ideas developed into concept note/proposal ix. MEA Reports for SE4ALL and UNFCCC meetings
Output 2: Mechanisms in place to assess and mitigate natural and man-made risks at the subnational level i. Meteorological equipment needs identified and costed for set up in high climate disaster risk areas ii. Climate disaster database needs list iii. Global DRM event Reports iv. Floodplain Management Framework
Output 3: Project effectively planned, implemented and monitored i. Project coordination and management mechanism in place. MOUs with IP and RPs; Coordinator; Assistant; ii. AWP, 4 costed QWP, 4 Quarterly reports and budgets. iii. Two project ideas and Pipeline projects developed to mobilise

Output 1: Scaled up action on climate change adaptation and mitigation in vulnerable districts is funded and implemented At the sub-national level, the project was introduced to all the five districts in which community level adaptation and mitigation interventions are to be implemented. Furthermore one technical partner and two CSOs operating in two of the districts (Buhera and Chiredzi) were identified as local level implementing partners whose ongoing project activities in the GEF/UNDP Scaling Up Adaptation project can be enhanced through the SECA Project. UNV project officers were recruited during the course of the year and commenced work in the last quarter of the year in Bulilima, Lupane and Gokwe South. Baseline study is ongoing in Gokwe South, Lupane and Bulilima. The development of district and ward level gender and climate sensitive DRM Plans moved to 2017. During the year, the project provided significant support to the crafting of the Renewable Energy Policy and the National Forest Policy through funding some of the main consultative workshops and by providing technical support on climate change. The Renewable Energy Policy now awaits a final stakeholder endorsement meeting to be conducted in February 2017 whilst the National Forest Policy has been validated and is being finalized before being presented to other arms of government for scrutiny. The project funded capacity development for private sector engagement in the Clean Development Mechanism and low carbon development strategy in line with the objectives of the countrys Nationally Determined Contributions to the UNFCCC. A number of companies have embarked on CDM project development. The process for developing a Low Carbon Development Strategy has not advanced significantly. The project provided support for capacity building on Green Climate Fund proposal development for two Ministry of Environment, Water and Climate officers. In collaboration among MEWC/UNDP/Climate Resilient Infrastructure Dev

Output 1: Scaled up action on climate change adaptation and mitigation in vulnerable districts is funded and implemented i. National Adaptation Plan finalised ii. 2016 HDR finalised and launched iii. RE policy finalised. iv. More efficient EIS with mapping capabilities v. Schools RE resources book finalised vi. Climate and energy information disseminated vii. GCF proposal finalised. Mitigation concept note developed viii. Recommendations on planning, policy and strategy provided with a basis in participation in UNFCCC and relevant energy/mitigation fora.
Output 2: Mechanisms in place to assess and mitigate natural and man-made risks at the subnational level i. Indicators for SFDRR developed ii. Climate resilient infrastructure guide for schools developed iii. Updated DRM plans for Bulilima, Gokwe South, Lupane iv. Recommendations provided for DRM in policy, planning and programming.
Output 3: Project effectively planned, implemented and monitored i. Baseline study document finalised and recommendations feeding into design of project interventions ii. AWP, 4 costed QWP, 4 Quarterly reports and budgets.

Output 1: Scaled up action on climate change adaptation and mitigation in vulnerable districts is funded and implemented i. This target was changed to National Adaptation Plan stocktaking exercise finalised due to that the MEWC has accessed GCF readiness funding for the development of the NAP. The NAP stocktaking was extended to Q1 2018 to allow for urban adaptation issues to also be considered. Urban authorities were engaged in November 2017 in partnership with the UNDP Local Government project with success. There is interest from urban authortities and expectations of continued partnership to support urban adaptation and resilience. ii. Climate focused HDR finalised. Awaiting launch. iii. RE policy was finalised and is awaiting cabinet approval. Forestry policy finalised and awaiting cabinet approval. iv. The MoEPD officers were trained in GIS to support RE mappings in November. Yet to register results in terms of actual mappings. v. The schools energy book process was kickstarted with a meeting. A UNICEF paid consultant is currently working on the RE resources book and UNICEF is following the process through with additional funding vi. Climate and energy information disseminated at Zimbabwe Agricultural Show and Zimbabwe International Trade Fair. Articles submitted to Sustain magazine readership 10.000. Promotional materials were created for Zimbabwe Agricultural Show and ZITF Visitors to the stand were provided with information on the SECA project and climate smart agriculture as well as what the Government of Zimbabwe is doing in response to climate change. Several groups of people visited the stand including Farmers, Students, Private Organisations, CSOs and other Government Departments and Parastatals. The project team did not do a count/estimate of number of people reached. vii. GCF proposal is near completion, final tranches to consultant to be paid in December 2017 and internal review to be carried out in January 2018. Submission to GCF for July boar

1.a. A Government platform on Peace and Social Cohesion is established 1.b. A Government-led framework facilitating the coordination of peace actors at the national and local level in Zimbabwe is adopted and implemented 2. a. NPRC and its Secretariat are equipped to effectively execute its Constitutional mandate 2. b. National Framework and Implementation Plan for Reconciliation in place 2.c. Number of NPRC internal organizational tools developed and utilized 2.d. Database of actioned early warning signals for timely response established 3.a. A framework for multi-stakeholder processes for consensus building on shared values is designed and piloted 4.a. No. of LPCs who are providing dispute resolution and mediation services [dis-aggregated by No. of LPCs in place, No. of Peace mediators (PM) including No. of women, men and youth, No. of Peace dividends initiatives] 4.b.A Dispute Management System for Local Peace Committees with at least 200 cases successfully resolved and documented is in place

comment.narrative: 1.a. There is currently no joint inter ministerial entity working on peace and social cohesion 2.a.The NPRC was established by the 2013 Constitution, Commissioners were sworn in on 24th February 2016 2.b. There is no national framework and implementation plan for reconciliation 2.c There is no NPRC internal organizational tools in place to guide the NPRCs work 2.d A draft framework for the establishment of the CEWER has been designed 3. 0 4.a. 188 (LPCs); 179 (PM); 4 (Peace Dividends) 4.b. Absence of a dispute management system to track the number of cases resolved

1. A Government Working Group on Peace and Social Cohesion is established 2. a. NPRC and its Secretariat is in place 2.b. A draft Internal Reconciliation and Peacebuilding Strategy is designed ; At least 1 national awareness & consensus building session convened 2.c. At least 2 drafts are developed 2. d. A working group is established to design the CEWER mechanism; 3. DRG with 20 Members in place; At least 4 high level platforms for stakeholder dialogue established 4.a 50 LPCs (in 2 selected districts); 50 PM; 20 Peace dividend Programmes 4.b A dispute management system is set up with 50 cases documented

1. For 2016, and as informed by the withdrawal of the NPRC Bill from Parliament, the focus for the OPC has been on facilitating multi-stakeholder input into the draft NPRC Bill. 2.a An Induction and Orientation Programme was delivered for the sworn-in NPRC Commissioners to equip them with skills and competencies in preparation for carrying out their mandate. As part of the roll out of the plan, the Capacity Enhancement Retreats contributed to laying the foundations for confidence, cohesion and trust building within the Commission, as well as sensitization to key concepts and enablers of facilitating peace and reconciliation. 2.b & c The 9 Commissioners were sworn in in February 2016, however the enabling legislation is not yet in place. Finalization of the NPRC Act is expected for 2017. 2.d Three initial consultative meetings have been held within Civil Society Organizations leading to the identification of three capacity development needs around: a) development of an Indicator Databank / Dashboard for effective data collection; b)Capacities for data collection, verification, validation, analyzing and reporting for response. (Tools & Methodologies and Incentives); Capacities for mobilizing multiple stakeholder responses through constructive and sustained engagement strategies. Further efforts will resume in 2017. 3. A multi-sectoral dialogue space entitled The Champions Dialogue Group or Dialogue Reference Group (composed of 15 selected leaders) initiated in April 2016, has since met four times leading to the definition of shared and common identify, the identification of common issues of interests and the mapping of capacity needs. In addition, three other high level dialogue platforms were supported in 2016 including the Creative Arts and Culture Leaders Forum (initiated in September 2016), the Zimbabwe Heads of Christian Denominations (ZHOCD) in spearheading dialogue and reconciliation efforts, and the CSOs dialogue platform on EWER. 4. a. 36 LPCs have dem

1. Through the coordination role of the OPC, two joint Programme Steering Committee field visits were organized to Mudzi/Mutoko from March 20-24th and to Zaka 4 7th June 2017. These field visits provided stakeholders in the broader peace community the opportunity to receive community testimonials in an effort to better understand the role played by local community structures, jointly reflect on how to better support the contribution made by these structures towards strengthening the broader peace architecture.
1.a Government through the OPC provided leadership in coordination of peace actors through convening of technical meetings. One Technical Committee Meeting (12th January), and four Programme Steering Committee Meetings (19th January, 5th April, 21st June and 19th July) were convened bringing together various stakeholders under the project to engage on critical issues of peace building and social cohesion in the Zimbabwean context. 1.b. The project provided technical support to the OPC during the drafting of the NPRC Bill which was passed by Parliament in October 2017, and is currently awaiting presidential assent. The passing of the Bill into law is part of creation of that framework for enabling peace with the full operationalisation of the NPRC mandate
1.b. In anticipation of the final signing of the Bill into an Act, a team of technical experts from the region was established to support the development of the NPRC draft regulations, which will be the legal framework that will guide the operations of the NPRC. Draft NPRC General Regulations were reviewed by a Panel of Experts. Working Draft has now been shared by the experts.
1.b. On the 30th of November 2017, the Commission convened its maiden stakeholder engagement session which resolved to convene a national convergence and dialogue on Reconciliation. A communique was produced to this effect and has been submitted to media houses for publication. The communique was published on the 5th of Decemb

Indicator 1 1.a. During the course of the year, the project supported the development of the electronic Case Management System which computerises and automates the workflow for all complaints and investigations, thereby, improving management of cases. As 2017 is the second year of implementation deployment of the case management system is expected to support measurement of the percentage of cases of human rights and maladministration resolved, tracked and referred.
1.b. Two Children's homes and 4 old people's homes and 4 prison monitoring visits were conducted and recommendations to duty bearers made by the ZHRC. Indicator 2 2.a. Citizens engagement and participation was increased through over 8 outreaches and road shows which were conducted in 3 provinces to increase visibility of the Commission as the lead institution in the protection, promotion and enforcement of human rights as well as impart knowledge on human rights to citizens. Over 4000 citizens were reached through a human rights awareness outreach programme that targets vulnerable group such as women and persons with disability. Scooping missions and a baseline study was conducted and a report on the essentials needed to establish and operationalize Human Rights Centres and Mobile centers is in place.
Indicator 3 3.a. Four (4) TWG, Childrens Right TWG (CR - TWG), Gender Equality and Womens Rights TWG (GE&WR TWG), Special Interest Groups (SIG - TWG) and Environmental Rights (ER - TWG) became operational, developed workplans, conducted quarterly engagements with stakeholders, initiative thematic focussed work among them Report on the San Indigenous minorities, investigative visits for environmentally affected areas in Zvishavane capacity building workshops. Results Indicator 1.5: SDGs localisation framework in place and being implemented. Results Indicator 2.1: Enhanced skills and Competencies (financial management, governance, leadership) of professionals in the Local Government Sector Results Indicator 2.2: Enhanced Business processes and systems (financial, human resources, infrastructure) in Local Authorities Results Indicator 2.3: Local Economic Development Ventures Results Indicator 2.4: Efficient and Effective Revenue Collection and Generation in the local government sector Results Indicator 2.5: Piloting 3 alternative Service Delivery Models Results Indicator 3.1: Citizen Participation and Engagement Policy Results Indicator 3.2: Strengthened sub-national participatory structures (WARDCs, VIDCOs and Traditional Leadership) Results Indicator 4.1: Organisational Learning in the Local Government Sector Results Indicator 4.2: ICT Strategy Recommendations Implemented. Results Indicator 4.3: Two (2) Local Government Knowledge Institutions Capacity Enhanced Results Indicator 5.1: Gender Responsive Local Government Policy Results Indicator 5.2: Gender sensitive service delivery indicators Results Indicator 5.3: Gender Mainstreaming Capacity in the Local Government and responsible Ministries enhanced.

comment.narrative:
Result Indicator 1.1. Baseline (2016): There is no local government legislation aligned to the constitution. There are 30 pieces of legislation that need to be aligned. Result Indicator 1.2. There is no national Local Government Policy. Result Indicator 1.3 WASH sector service level benchmark for urban local authorities is in place. Result Indicator 1.4 There is no service delivery monitoring and evaluation framework. Result Indicator 1.5 There is no SDGs Localisation Framework.
Result Indicator 2.1. Capacity Assessment Report 2013 Result Indicator 2.2 Weak business processes and challenging easy of doing business context in the local government sector Result Indicator 2.3 There are limited LED interventions in local government Result Indicator 2.4 average 40% revenue collection efficiency Result Indicator 2.5 Few Initiatives on Alternative Service Delivery Models (TBA on specificities)
Result Indicator 3.1 No citizen participation and engagement policy Result Indicator 3.2 The capacity of the sub-national participatory planning structures is reported to be weak (TBA after the assessment)
Result Indicator 4.1 Limited organisational learning happening. Result Indicator 4.2 Limited use of ICT Result Indicator 4.3 TBA
Result Indicator 5.1 No gender responsive Local Government policy Result Indicator 5.2 There are no gender sensitive service delivery indicators Result Indicator 5.3 TBA

Result Indicator 1.1 The Local Authorities Bills presented to Parliament. Result Indicator 1.2 National Local Government Policy drafted. Result Indicator 1.3 Data to develop the SLB Framework gathered. Result Indicator 1.4 Monitoring and Evaluation Framework piloted in 30% of the local Authorities. Result Indicator 1.5 Draft SGDs localisation Framework.
Result Indicator 2.1 Rapid capacity assessment of the selected local authorities and capacity development plans per local authority Result Indicator 2.2 Business processes in local authorities assessed and intervention plans developed. Result Indicator 2.3 Local Economic Development Opportunities and challenges per Local Authorities identifies and LED strategies developed Result Indicator 2.4 an assessment report of the factors impeding revenue collection and generation. Result Indicator 2.5 A study into the state of play in terms of Service Delivery Models
Result Indicator 3.1 Draft citizen participation and engagement policy. Result Indicator 3.2 The capacity of the sub-national participatory planning structures developed (TBA after the assessment)
Result Indicator 4.1 Organisational learning system installed and functional in the selected local authorities Result Indicator 4.2 All Local Authorities with functional ICT and connectivity Result Indicator 4.3 Assessment of the capacities of the knowledge institutions to support the local government sector and development of intervention plans
Result Indicator 5.1 Gender marker for the ministries.

1.1 National consultations on the Traditional Leaders Bill (5 provinces) was conducted and the drafting process of the Bill has commenced. The Local Authorities Bills is still under review before it's presented to Parliament. 1.2 Drafting of the Rural Development Strategy is in place and awaits validation. 1.3 Draft SLB Framework developed for various service lines (roads, social amenities, governance, planning and settlements, street lighting) to be adopted by Local Authorities. 1.4 Draft M&E framework in the final stages and M&E training for M&E Officers in the two ministries conducted.
2.1 Assess the capacity of 10 Local authorities (5rural and 5 urban) to done in Q4. 2.2 The Orientation and Induction of new personnel in the two Ministries on the business processes was done at the Highlands Training Centre. 2.3 The Local Economic Development Opportunities and challenges per Local Authorities identifies and LED strategies is still pending. 2.4 An assessment report of the factors impeding revenue collection and generation is still pending.
3.1 Draft citizen participation and engagement policy is pending in Q4. 3.2 Development of Me and My Council handbook developed to inform the public and guide local authorities on their mandates.
4.1 The identification of the learning needs of the personnel in the two Ministries is still pending. 4.2 All Local Authorities with functional ICT and connectivity is still pending. 4.3 Engagement of Midlands State of University (MSU) on Local Economic Development conducted and a Post-Graduate Diploma course outline was jointly developed by MSU.
5.1 A Gender Marker Training was held for the Gender Focal Persons in the two local government ministries and ToRs for the focal persons are being drafted.

1. Capacity Assessments (including revenue generation, collection efficiency and local economic development) of at least six selected local authorities undertaken. 2. Service Level Benchmarking (Baselines, Performance Improvement Plans, and M&E Plans) of at least two selected local authorities setup. 3. Draft National Rural Development Strategy developed. 4. Regional, Country and Planning Act reviewed and draft amendments developed. 5. Finalise the draft citizen participation and engagement framework. 6. Draft Gender Responsive Local Government Policy developed. 7. Establish Gender Sensitive Service Delivery Indicators Framework.

1. In aligning laws to the Constitution, the Ministries of local government dialogued with the Attorney Generals Office to refine and conclude the draft Local Government Bill. A preliminary review of the Regional, Town and Country Act was undertaken and draft amendments were identified for consultations with stakeholders.
2. Following the 2016 Capacity Assessments of Chirumanzu and Uzumba-Maramba-Pfungwe RDCs, Performance Improvement Plans (PIPs) for the two RDCs on infrastructure, road networks, waste management, industrialization, environment, food security and governance were developed and adopted by the respective Councils.
3. 60 Rural District Authorities identified the services for benchmarking and the service level benchmarking data collection tools were developed, including questionnaires for use by Councils to monitor and assess progress in achieving the benchmarks. Roll out of SLB tools will commence in 19 pilot RDCs next year.
4. Non-WASH SLB indicators and data collection tools for the Urban Local Authorities were developed and piloting phase agreed. The Non-WASH services comprise roads and traffic management indicators, housing and community services, corporate governance, financial management, health services and development control.
5. The Government led Ease of Doing Business (EoDB) was rolled out in all local authorities, positively enhancing especially rural local authorities business processes, revenue collection, accountability, resolving institutional and policy bottlenecks in administration of shared infrastructure and natural resources, such as land, water, roads, wildlife, levies, taxes and tariffs.
6. A draft National Local Economic Development (LED) framework was developed, peer-reviewed by a Team comprising LED Practitioners, Government Ministries and Office of the President and Cabinet. The draft was debated at the LED Symposium hosted by the Midlands State University (MSU) in partnership with Practitioners, Municipal Instit

- Citizens perception study report printed - Prison Decongestion Concept Note finalized - Assessment of decentralization of legal services conducted - IMC State Party Reporting implementation plan developed - Sensitization session on human rights and Policy makers role in State Party reporting held - UPR publicity campaign at ZITZ exhibition convened

UPR report for second cycle finalised. UPR Campaign strategy adopted and rolled out with mock session on UPR done, UPR Jingles aired, Press Briefing on UPR held, Press statements done, Interviews done.
IMC capacity development plan done following an IMC strategic planning and review meeting. JLOS case handling system TORs developed and Prison Decongestion Concept Note finalised for adoption by Policy Heads.

-Developed Capacity in M&E, Gender mainstreaming -Case and grievance handling system developed -Legal Aid Coordination framework -IMC State Party Reporting training conducted -Draft Report to the African Commission on the ACHPR -UPR second cycle recommendations received

2017 RESULTS Indicator 1 While no percentage of cases addressed can be reported at this time in the implementation of the project, support has been provided towards the development of a Legal Aid coordination framework which was adopted as part of the framework for coordination of legal aid services as well as standardising and increasing legal aid services to indigent persons. It now awaits validation and adoption following consultative stakeholder meetings in the northern and southern provinces attended by actors and legal aid services providers. Implementation is forecasted for next year as the target for 2017 which was developing this framework is almost complete. The development of a legal aid framework further facilitates the establishment of the coordination mechanism of legal aid providers including establishment of referral system.
Indicator 2. IMC capacity building training on the new state party reporting procedures was conducted and completed for the whole IMC. These skills acquired enabled the drafting of various state party reports by the IMC. The African Commission on Human and Peoples Right (ACHPR) report was finalised and now awaits adoption while the development of the UN Common Core Document was also done and the draft CRPD report in now in place. These 3 reports speaking to sub-indicator 2.e. await Cabinet approval before submission to various Treaty Monitoring Bodies. Meanwhile, the UPR implementation tools (NPA, M&E, capacity needs and information for data base) were developed and adopted following receipt of recommendations from UN Human Rights Council. 151 recommendations were accepted in full, 6 in part and 103 noted. These tools will enable effective tracking in the implemented of the accepted recommendations.
